author: By Anton Troianovski
title: Patient and Confident, Putin Shifts Out of Wartime Crisis Mode
description: Cloistered and spouting grievances at the start of the war on Ukraine, the Russian leader now appears publicly, projecting the aura of a calm, paternalistic leader shielding his people from the dangers of the world.
content: Early in his war against Ukraine, President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia appeared tense, angry and even disoriented. He spent days out of the public eye, threatened the West with nuclear strikes, and lashed out at antiwar Russians as “scum.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ginia Bellafante
title: Can It Get Any Worse for Rudy Giuliani?
description: The former mayor’s response to a hostile encounter with a grocery worker on Staten Island has left even his defenders baffled.
content: “When did Rudy Giuliani go off the rails?” is a question that many Americans and New Yorkers in particular have been asking for years now, arriving at no obvious consensus. Old-time observers of the local political scene like to revisit the time, two decades ago, when he famously berated an advocate of ferret ownership during a radio show, telling him that he needed “help” and that his “excessive concern with little weasels” was a “sickness.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Liptak, Miriam Jordan and Eileen Sullivan
title: Supreme Court Sides With Biden’s Efforts to End ‘Remain in Mexico’ Program
description: The program, adopted during the Trump administration, requires some migrants to wait in Mexico while their cases are heard.
content: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court ruled on Thursday that the Biden administration may rescind a Trump-era immigration program that forces certain asylum seekers arriving at the southwestern border to await approval in Mexico.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tejal Rao
title: Heatless Cooking for Hot Days
description: You don’t have to light a grill to make the most of summer produce.
content: I was so excited to buy my first full-size grill, but now that I have it all cleaned up and parked in the backyard, I have to admit that it feels too hot to babysit a grill outside. I’m sure I’ll change my mind soon, but not this weekend! I’m planning meals around recipes that require little to no heat at all.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Sanders, M.D
title: He Could Barely Walk and Had to Give Up Golf. What Was Wrong?
description: Over six years, many doctors told the patient he had peripheral neuropathy. What they couldn’t tell him was why — or how to treat it.
content: It was in spring that the 69-year-old man missed playing golf the most. How he loved the cool South Carolina mornings, the feel of the club in his hands, his arms and his body moving in that perfect arc. But even before he had to stop, he noticed changes. The sensation in his fingers slowly disappeared, then their strength. He gave up the game after he nearly clobbered a friend; his club flew right out of his hands at the end of his stroke. Missed him by inches.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Livia Albeck-Ripka
title: No Staff. No Supply. No Rain: Some Cities Call Off July 4 Fireworks.
description: Supply chain and staffing shortages, concerns over wildfires and drought have led cities to call off their Independence Day shows. For some, it’s the third year in a row.
content: The night skies of some American cities will remain dark this Independence Day, with supply chain and staffing shortages, drought and concerns over wildfires leading to the cancellation of several fireworks shows across the country.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jack Tamisiea
title: Who’s Got Two Pseudothumbs and Loves to Eat Bamboo? This Bear.
description: Fossils found in southwestern China give a hint to the development of the panda’s sixth digit — a rudimentary, thumblike bone extension.
content: Giant pandas are dietary enigmas. Despite being part of the meat-eating order Carnivora, pandas typically practice a plant-based diet, eschewing salmon and seal meat at the bear family barbecue for shoots of bamboo. And because they lack multichambered stomachs to extract nutrients from the tough plant material, the pudgy bears eat around 30 pounds of bamboo each day to sustain themselves.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Manohla Dargis
title: ‘The Forgiven’ Review: When the Haves Dispose of a Have-Not
description: Ralph Fiennes and Jessica Chastain play an unhappy couple who accidentally kill a stranger in Morocco en route to a desert bacchanal.
content: “They were careless people,” the narrator in “The Great Gatsby” says of two of that novel’s wealthiest, cruelest characters; “they smashed up things and creatures.” They would probably get along with the similarly careless wretches who populate “The Forgiven,” though especially the unhappily married couple who smash into a teenager, killing him.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Blinder and Billy Witz
title: U.C.L.A. and U.S.C. Poised to Join Big Ten, Rattling College Sports Anew
description: The move by two of the Pac-12 Conference’s marquee schools came as the Big Ten closed in on a new television deal.
content: Southern California and U.C.L.A. moved Thursday to defect to the Big Ten Conference from the Pac-12, sparking another seismic remaking of the competitive and economic landscapes of college sports.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Traub
title: 1955 Arrest Warrant in Emmett Till Case Is Found in Court Basement
description: The document charges the woman whose accusations led to the Black teenager’s murder with his kidnapping. The warrant was never served — and she is still alive.
content: A team of researchers including relatives of Emmett Till, the 14-year-old Black boy who was abducted and murdered in Mississippi in 1955, has discovered an unserved arrest warrant for the white woman whose accusations led to his gruesome death.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Kennedy
title: ‘Beauty’ Review: Requiem for a Pop Star
description: The ghost of Whitney Houston haunts “Beauty,” the story of a singer, her family and best friend on the edge of fame.
content: Befitting its title, “Beauty” opens looking lovely, even if much of what transpires in this story of a Black pop star set to ink a record deal will be ugly. Played by Gracie Marie Bradley, Beauty stands in front of a microphone in a recording studio. This close-up image will be repeated several times, challenging timeline expectations by looping what will be with what is.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tiffany May
title: An Instagram hot spot becomes a display of loyalty to the mainland.
description: Hundreds of crimson Chinese flags appeared on the white balconies on two 28-story buildings in a soaring residential complex.
content: The Ping Shek Estate has long been a magnet for Instagrammers eager to take snapshots of the sky framed on all four sides by the apartment complex’s soaring residential towers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By A.O. Scott
title: ‘Hallelujah’ Review: From Leonard Cohen to Cale to Buckley to Shrek
description: A new documentary tells the entwined stories of a songwriter and his best-known composition.
content: Leonard Cohen’s final album, released in October 2016, is called “You Want It Darker.” He died on Nov. 7, the day before the U.S. presidential election, and in the years since, things have grown very dark indeed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eduardo Medina
title: John Visentin, Xerox C.E.O., Dies at 59
description: He had sought to broaden the company’s offerings beyond photocopying and printing. Xerox said he died of “complications from an ongoing illness.”
content: John Visentin, who as chief executive led Xerox through the pandemic at a time when demand for printed documents and ink waned, died on Tuesday. He was 59.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hannah Beech and Sergey Ponomarev
title: ‘Everything in Hong Kong Has Changed’: A Road to Reinvention
description: In the 25 years since the handover to China, life on Queen’s Road, the first thoroughfare built by the British after they seized the territory, has been transformed.
content: HONG KONG — On the day that Hong Kong was returned to China a quarter century ago, the noodle maker of Queen’s Road worked as he had done for days and decades before, mixing flour and water into sustenance for a city filled with refugees from the mainland. To satisfy the diverse tastes, he made tender Shanghai noodles and Cantonese egg pasta, slippery wonton wrappers from China’s south and thick dumpling skins beloved in Beijing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Hodgman
title: Judge John Hodgman on the Doughnut Birthday
description: A 10-year-old wishes to gorge himself on his special day.
content: Ryan writes: Our son is turning 10 in September. In lieu of a birthday cake, he wants to eat two dozen doughnuts in one sitting. He is convinced he can do it. We are certain that it will end in sickness or a lifelong doughnut aversion. Please order him not to do this.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Casselman
title: Pessimism about the economy is growing, a U.S. poll shows.
description: Roughly half of those surveyed say they are worse off financially than a year ago, and most disapprove of President Biden’s handling of inflation.
content: Americans are becoming more pessimistic about the economy, more worried about inflation — and now, more anxious about the job market, as well.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gail Collins
title: The Supreme Court Takes Us Back … Way Back
description: Think about what the world was really like before Roe.
content: Everybody’s been talking about the comments Supreme Court Justice Clarence Thomas made during his portion of the Dobbs decision. You know, where he basically said birth control and gay marriage are up next.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Choe Sang-Hun and David Yaffe-Bellany
title: How North Korea Used Crypto to Hack Its Way Through the Pandemic
description: The isolated country continues to find ways to evade sanctions and generate income while operating on the fringes of the global financial system.
content: SEOUL — North Korea’s economy has been ravaged by United Nations sanctions and the coronavirus pandemic. The government has warned of a severe food shortage. An unidentified intestinal disease began spreading among citizens in June.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rhonda Garelick
title: Muted Tones Spoke Loud and Clear
description: At a surprise session of the Jan. 6 hearings, Cassidy Hutchinson calibrated her appearance to keep us listening.
content: This week, a calm, even-toned conversation between two carefully dressed Republican women, Cassidy Hutchinson and Representative Liz Cheney, created one of the most explosive and riveting television events of the decade.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patrick Kingsley
title: Israel’s Parliament Dissolves, Paving Way for 5th Election in 4 Years
description: The decision brought down the coalition government and installed Yair Lapid, a centrist, as interim prime minister. Exhausted and exasperated Israelis will be asked to vote again in November.
content: JERUSALEM — Israeli lawmakers voted to dissolve Parliament on Thursday, collapsing the government, installing a caretaker prime minister and sending an exhausted electorate to a fifth election in less than four years.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Amber Rose Is Not Who You Think She Is
description: As the public figure resurrects her SlutWalk (and releases a rap single), she’s looking to cast off the labels of her past.
content: It was 10 years ago that the host of a popular morning radio show told Amber Rose during an interview that, until recently, he thought she should be “seen and not heard.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By April Rubin
title: An Excavation in the Sea Depths Recovers Hercules From the Afterlife
description: An ancient shipwreck off the coast of Greece is yielding secrets as an archaeological exploration project dives deeper. The effort relies on technological innovation.
content: As myth has it, Hercules had to complete 12 heroic labors to be absolved of guilt and to become immortal. A recent discovery picks up the story, long after the Greek and Roman tales concluded, to tell us a new version of his afterlife.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amy Nicholson
title: ‘Mr. Malcolm’s List’ Review: A Finalist for His Affection
description: Upper-crust courtship comes with undercooked social commentary in this Regency-era romance.
content: A tepid Regency-era romance, “Mr. Malcolm’s List” hinges on Jeremy Malcolm (Sope Dirisu), a wealthy, aloof bachelor looking for a woman who meets his 10-point checklist for a suitable mate. The trouble starts when Malcolm rejects Julia Thistlewaite (Zawe Ashton), a singleton who fails Point No. 4 — “converses in a sensible fashion” — and is publicly humiliated by Malcolm, who yawns behind her back. Vowing vengeance, Julia schemes to manipulate the snob into falling in love with her childhood friend Selina Dalton (Freida Pinto), a country naïf whom Julia presents, through bits of trickery, as Malcolm’s dream bride. (In one scene, Selina is made to look like a piano virtuoso.) Selina doesn’t so much agree to her bossy chum’s plan as succumb to it, like a leaf drifting downstream.
source.name: The New York Times

title: How New York Times reporters avoid personal involvement in politics
description: Explaining the policies and processes that define our journalism.
content: Our ethics guidelines state that journalists have no place on the playing fields of politics. Of course, staff members are entitled to vote, but they must do nothing that might raise questions about their professional neutrality or that of The Times.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Margaret Fuhrer
title: Where TikTok-Like Dance Challenges Meet Network TV
description: “Dancing With Myself,” on NBC, shows the deep influence of the dance challenge on popular culture, even as its hold on TikTok has loosened.
content: Even by the razzle-dazzle standards of TV talent competitions, “Dancing With Myself” sets an impressive scene. Two stacked rows of room-size cubes, trimmed in shimmering lights, fill the stage — “Hollywood Squares” meets “Saturday Night Fever.” At the judging table sit the pop stars Shakira and Nick Jonas and the internet celebrity Liza Koshy; behind them, a cheering studio audience. One cube’s door slides open to reveal the show’s first contestant, who begins to perform …
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Valeriya Safronova
title: A Party Crawl With Pussy Riot’s Nadya Tolokonnikova
description: At 21, she was a founding member of the Russian anti-government punk collective. At 22, she was imprisoned. A decade later, she’s still fighting, this time using cryptocurrency to help her subvert the system.
content: “I’m a super-introvert,” said Nadezhda Tolokonnikova, one of the founding members of Pussy Riot, as the elevator zoomed to the Rainbow Room on the 65th floor of Rockefeller Center, where the NFT Now gala was in full swing on June 21.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brenna M. Casey
title: A Sculptor Takes His Craft to the Skies
description: The artist Desmond Lewis brings the glow of professional fireworks to under-resourced communities in the South.
content: GREENWOOD, Miss. — On Saturday night, June 18, the Memphis-based artist Desmond Lewis was in a public park unloading cakes — bundles of fireworks connected by a high-speed fuse — from a pickup truck. On the other side of a nearby tree line waited about 150 expectant onlookers for the Juneteenth celebration in the city that is heralded as “the cotton capital of the world.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Barron
title: The Lightning Rod Issue That Looms Over the Governor’s Race
description: Lee Zeldin, the Republican candidate, is anti-abortion, while Gov. Kathy Hochul is a strong backer of abortion rights.
content: Good morning. It’s Thursday. We’ll look at how the abortion issue divides the two major-party candidates for governor. We’ll also find out why dolphins are making a comeback in New York Harbor.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Why does The New York Times use anonymous sources?
description: Explaining the policies and processes that define our journalism.
content: “Speaking on the condition of anonymity …”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bonnie Kristian
title: The End of Roe, the End of Trump
description: After Dobbs, the Republican Party doesn’t need Trump.
content: For many backers of former President Donald Trump, Friday’s Supreme Court decision was a long-awaited vindication.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aurelien Breeden and Constant Méheut
title: Belgian Court Finds 10 Guilty Over Ties to Paris Attacks in November 2015
description: The convictions followed the end of a giant trial in the French capital over the same massacre, in which 130 people were killed.
content: PARIS — A Belgian court on Thursday found 10 people guilty of providing assistance to the Islamist terrorist group that killed 130 people in and around Paris in 2015.  Sentences for some of those convicted ranged from 100 hours of community service to a three-year suspended prison sentence.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By German Lopez
title: A Powerful Court
description: In other advanced democracies, the courts are more restrained.
content: By now, most of us are used to U.S. Supreme Court rulings that bring big changes to American life — on abortion, guns, same-sex marriage and more. This morning may bring another sweeping ruling, on climate change.
source.name: The New York Times

title: 10 New Books We Recommend This Week
description: Suggested reading from critics and editors at The New York Times.
content: Cultural life, broadly defined, looms large among this week’s recommended books, from a scholar’s freewheeling treatise on Marcel Proust to a bike rider’s paean to wheeling free. Frederic Tuten’s story collection pays frequent homage to the artists and writers of earlier generations, David Hackett Fischer’s latest history celebrates Black contributions to American culture, and the group biography “Metaphysical Animals” looks back on a group of remarkable women who became friends at Oxford in the 1940s, bonding over their shared skepticism about prevailing philosophical ideas.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hilarie M. Sheets
title: Foreland, an Art Complex With Big Ambitions, Grows in Catskill
description: As its new gallery spaces open for the season July 1, Foreland’s founder, Stef Halmos, talks of building community in the sprawling Hudson Valley scene.
content: CATSKILL, N.Y. — When the artist Stef Halmos moved to New York City in 2012 with a master's degree in fine art, she tried in vain to find a decent and affordable studio space. “The sprinklers didn’t work, there was no natural light, there was a curtain for a door — that’s what you would get,” said Halmos. “I just knew I could do it better.” It helped to have a family in the real estate business.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By C. J. Hughes
title: Homes for Sale in New York City
description: This week’s available properties are on the Lower East Side, in Sutton Place and in Greenpoint.
content: Click on the slide show to see this week’s featured properties:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emmett Lindner
title: Editing With a Reporter’s Instinct
description: Four New York Times editors, once reporters or photographers themselves, reflect on how their experiences in the field inform their editing now.
content: Reporters and editors exist in an ecosystem that works to take an idea and shape it into an article. The relationship can be symbiotic and, at times, contentious. But at its best, editors and reporters work together to make the article both descriptive and accurate. Four New York Times editors shared how their prior reporting experiences strengthened their ability to edit. Read their edited reflections below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marc Santora and Ivan Nechepurenko
title: Ukraine drives Russian forces from Snake Island, a setback for Moscow.
description: The retreat came after sustained Ukrainian attacks, including with newly arrived Western weapons, made it impossible for Russian forces to hold the island.
content: Russian troops have withdrawn from Snake Island in the Black Sea after repeated assaults by Ukrainian forces, a move that is a setback for Moscow’s forces and possibly undermines their control over vital shipping lanes for grain in the Black Sea.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: June 30, 2022
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Thursday, June 30, 2022.
content: An article on Wednesday about growing safety concerns as New York City pools open amid a swim lesson shortage misstated the name of a nonprofit group offering free swim lessons. It is Friends of + POOL, not Plus Pools.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tania Ganguli and Sopan Deb
title: Kevin Durant Asks to Be Traded From the Nets
description: Durant has been with the Nets since 2019, but his tenure has been rocky between injuries, losses and turmoil among his teammates.
content: The Nets’ latest foray into the world of superteams might be over.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeannette Catsoulis
title: ‘Rubikon’ Review: Waiting to Inhale
description: In this somber morality tale, the bare-bones crew of a space station is faced with an impossible choice.
content: “Rubikon,” a talky, soporific sci-fi drama, is partly an environmental heads up and partly an ethical argument that hews mainly toward utilitarianism. Yet there’s sufficient ambivalence in the screenplay (by the Austrian director, Leni Lauritsch, and Jessica Lind) to suggest that, given the characters’ minuscule odds of long-term survival, their philosophical choices are less consequential than they appear.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Margaret Lyons
title: How Much Watching Time Do You Have This Weekend?
description: For this holiday weekend, our TV critic recommends a new sketch special, a returning space show and a trip into the woods.
content: ‘Would It Kill You to Laugh?’When to watch: Now, on Peacock.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Glenn Kenny
title: ‘Minions: The Rise of Gru’ Review: They’re Yellow but Not Mellow
description: This latest edition featuring the animated creatures is an origin story of sorts for their master, Gru.
content: The cartoon characters called Minions, sufficiently popular to anchor two ostensibly discrete animated film franchises, are diminutive capsule-shaped yellow yammerers outfitted in goggles and overalls, whose bearing for the most part is simultaneously hyper and insouciant. While one of their number seems a relatively competent D.J., the remainder of this innumerable lot aren’t very adept, especially as henchminions. Kids love them. Parents, as far as one can see, tolerate them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kashmir Hill
title: Deleting Your Period Tracker Won’t Protect You
description: Tweets telling women to do that went viral after Roe v. Wade was overturned, but experts say other digital data are more likely to reveal an illegal abortion.
content: In May 1972, the Chicago police raided a high-rise apartment where a group called the Jane Collective was providing abortions. It was the year before the Supreme Court’s Roe v. Wade decision gave women the constitutional right to decide whether to give birth, and abortion was a criminal offense in Illinois.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anna Grace Lee
title: A New York Homecoming for the ‘Queen of Hoops’
description: Jennifer Fisher, who started her jewelry business out of her SoHo bedroom, returns to the neighborhood with a brick-and-mortar store.
content: In New York’s SoHo area on a recent overcast afternoon, the windows of the new Jennifer Fisher store had a futuristic glow. Inside, women in flowing summer dresses and fitted denim browsed cases filled with gold-plated hoop earrings and customizable charms.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Liptak and Nick Corasaniti
title: Supreme Court to Hear Case on State Legislatures’ Power Over Elections
description: The case, about a North Carolina voting map, has the potential to amplify the influence of state lawmakers over federal elections.
content: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court announced on Thursday that it would hear a case that could radically reshape how federal elections are conducted by giving state legislatures independent power, not subject to review by state courts, to set election rules in conflict with state constitutions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Morgan Campbell
title: An Elite Fighter Wants to Face the Best. It’s Not That Simple.
description: Kayla Harrison is an Olympic judo champion and undefeated in mixed martial arts bouts. A victory over Amanda Nunes or Cris Justino would raise her profile, but she may never get the chance.
content: COCONUT CREEK, Fla. — If professional mixed martial arts were merely a sport and not a business, Kayla Harrison said she would match herself with Amanda Nunes, the former Ultimate Fighting Championship women’s bantamweight champion.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Frank Bruni
title: Was Jan. 6 Really ‘Un-American’?
description: Trump’s enduring popularity challenges the country’s ideals.
content: The portrait of Donald Trump that Cassidy Hutchinson painted in her testimony on Tuesday afternoon was devastating. That’s because of its style as well as its content. She used an unadorned (but, when quoting the former president, vulgar) vocabulary. She maintained a steady manner. Her voice was quiet. That bolstered her credibility and intensified the impact of her words.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daniel Naroditsky
title: Chess Replay: You Versus Steinitz
description: Take on Wilhelm Steinitz in a recreation of a 4th World Championship game in Havana, 1892.
content: This is Chess Replay, an interactive puzzle based on a historic chess game. As a solver, you embody a famous player during a critical game in his or her career. A new edition of this puzzle is published each week on Thursdays.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeanna Smialek
title: The Fed’s preferred inflation gauge hints at moderation in May.
description: The Personal Consumption Expenditure index, which the central bank officially targets, has been running hot for more than a year.
content: The Federal Reserve’s preferred inflation gauge remained high but showed glimmers of moderation in May, data released Thursday showed, at a moment when central bankers are watching each incoming price data point worriedly and are rapidly raising interest rates to wrestle cost increases under control.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sheryl Gay Stolberg
title: Fauci says he believes Paxlovid kept him out of the hospital, even though he tested positive again.
description: Dr. Anthony Fauci, President Biden’s top pandemic adviser, sought to discourage doubts about the antiviral drug Paxlovid following what appeared to be a “rebound” of Covid-19 after taking the pills.
content: Dr. Anthony S. Fauci, President Biden’s top medical adviser for the coronavirus pandemic, sought on Wednesday to discourage doubts about the antiviral drug Paxlovid after disclosing that he had suffered what appeared to be a “rebound” of Covid-19 after taking a five-day course of the pills.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charlie Savage
title: E.P.A. Ruling Is Milestone in Long Pushback to Regulation of Business
description: The decision created greater opportunities for business interests to challenge regulations, reflecting conservative legal theories developed to rein in administrative agencies.
content: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court ruling in the Environmental Protection Agency case on Thursday was a substantial victory for libertarian-minded conservatives who have worked for decades to curtail or dismantle modern-style government regulation of the economy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Glenn Kenny
title: ‘Fourth of July’ Review: Fraught Family Dynamics From Louis C.K.
description: The comedian directs, co-writes and takes a supporting role in this family dramedy. It’s not supposed to be his show, but it is anyway.
content: Jeff, a jazz pianist, is a recovering alcoholic who is almost three years sober. But he hasn’t quite begun to reap the gifts of his new state. In spite of his contented marriage, his soul is a bag of anxiety — one that both his A.A. sponsor and his therapist seem bent on stuffing anew. As Jeff contemplates, with dread, visiting his loutish family for Fourth of July week, the bag is set to burst.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roger Cohen
title: Vitaliy Kim, Master Motivator and Symbol of Ukraine’s Resistance
description: Applying the lessons of taekwondo, the regional military leader has rallied the embattled southern city of Mykolaiv.
content: MYKOLAIV, Ukraine — To win the war, says Vitaliy Kim, you need to love the war. “Love what you are doing, reconcile with the situation you are in, find something good in every circumstance, in small victories, in results.”
source.name: The New York Times

title: 5 Classical Music Albums You Can Listen to Right Now
description: Recordings of works by Julius Eastman and William Grant Still, as well as a new “La Traviata,” are among the highlights.
content: The once-forgotten compositions of Julius Eastman (1940-90) are outlines, as malleable as they are strong. You can do “Gay Guerrilla” with its original four pianos, or 11 electric guitars, or a varied quintet — and voice! Or something entirely different. In the second in a series of Eastman recordings, the Los Angeles ensemble Wild Up emphasizes this flexibility, including two versions each of “Buddha” and “Touch Him When,” alongside “Joy Boy” and “Stay On It.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Karan Deep Singh
title: To Save Its Honey Industry, Australia Is Killing Bees by the Millions
description: Australia is the only major honey-producing country that has so far managed to contain the spread of a mite fatal to bees. That distinction is now in peril.
content: The first step is pouring gasoline into the beehive. Then it’s time to wait. The job is finished when the hive is burned the next day.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steven Erlanger, Jim Tankersley, Michael D. Shear and Alan Yuhas
title: Biden Vows to Back Ukraine ‘as Long as It Takes’ Despite Economic Toll
description: NATO leaders concluded a summit with new commitments to a united front against Russian aggression, but they face the challenge of persuading their own people that it’s worth the cost.
content: MADRID — President Biden vowed on Thursday that the United States and NATO would support Ukraine for as long as necessary to repel Russia’s invasion, despite waves of economic pain rolling through world markets and voters’ homes, saying it was the Kremlin that had miscalculated in its aggression, and not the West in opposing it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Genzlinger
title: Arnold Skolnick, Whose Poster Embodied Woodstock, Dies at 85
description: On short notice, he created the bird-on-a-guitar design that advertised the 1969 festival — and became a symbol of the era.
content: Arnold Skolnick, who with only a few days to work designed what became one of the most familiar pop-culture images of its time, the poster for the original Woodstock music festival in 1969, died on June 15 in Amherst, Mass. He was 85.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Soumya Karlamangla
title: What Californians Love About Summer
description: Finding joy in a season of calamities.
content: California isn’t known for its distinct seasons, but if it were, summer wouldn’t be a top pick.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Karni
title: Ketanji Brown Jackson Becomes First Black Female Supreme Court Justice
description: Her confirmation comes as the newly expanded conservative majority moves to give states more control.
content: WASHINGTON — Ketanji Brown Jackson took the judicial oath just after noon on Thursday, becoming the first Black woman to serve on the Supreme Court.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma G. Fitzsimmons
title: New York City will offer Paxlovid at mobile testing sites, a first in the U.S.
description: Mayor Eric Adams says that offering immediate prescriptions to people who test positive at the mobile sites will help address concerns over inequities in distributing antiviral treatments.
content: New York City is creating the first mobile testing units in the United States that will allow people who test positive for the coronavirus to immediately receive for free the antiviral treatment Paxlovid.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Goldstein
title: Regulator in Puerto Rico suspends operations of Euro Pacific Bank.
description: An international group of tax authorities had moved two years ago to stop the boutique online bank from serving as a vehicle for suspected tax evasion and money laundering.
content: A bank regulator in Puerto Rico says it has suspended the operations of a boutique online bank that has been the focus of an international tax-evasion investigation and is owned by Peter Schiff, the outspoken libertarian economist and money manager.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Liptak
title: The Case Tests the Sweep of the ‘Major Questions Doctrine’
description: The court has used the doctrine assertively, notably in striking down the Biden administration’s efforts to address the coronavirus pandemic.
content: The “major questions doctrine” requires Congress to authorize in plain and direct language any sweeping actions by administrative agencies that could transform the economy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Haberman
title: Liz Cheney calls Trump ‘a domestic threat that we have never faced before.’
description: In a forceful speech, the congresswoman also denounced Republican leaders who had “made themselves willing hostages to this dangerous and irrational man.”
content: Representative Liz Cheney, the Wyoming Republican and vice chairwoman of the House committee investigating the Capitol riot of Jan. 6, 2021, described former President Donald J. Trump in stark terms on Wednesday night as a threat to the republic who had “gone to war with the rule of law.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Beandrea July
title: ‘Accepted’ Review: Reaching for the Stars, Seeing Them Dissolve
description: After a scandal unravels at their private school in western Louisiana, four seniors pick up the pieces.
content: In “Accepted” the director Dan Chen takes us inside the world of T.M. Landry, a Louisiana private school whose videos of African American students collecting Ivy League college acceptances once went viral. But nine months after the filmmakers’ first visit to the school, The New York Times published reports of physical abuse, falsified transcripts and “cultish” behavior on the part of its founders, Mike and Tracey Landry. Viewers of “Accepted” get a front-row seat to the life-altering impact of the school’s unraveling through the stories of four promising high school seniors: Adia, Alicia, Cathy and Issac.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Krugman
title: Crazies, Cowards and the Trump Coup
description: We need moral courage, but it’s very rare.
content: Like many people, I expected the worst from the Jan. 6 committee: long, droning speeches, grandstanding by posturing politicians, lots of he-said-she-said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Clay Risen
title: Martin C. Dreiwitz, Who Took Student Musicians on World Tours, Dies at 91
description: He combined his love for travel and music to turn the Long Island Youth Orchestra into a globe-trotting powerhouse.
content: Martin C. Dreiwitz, who drew on his twin passions for travel and classical music to found the globe-trotting Long Island Youth Orchestra, conducting his student musicians before audiences as close as Great Neck and Brookville and as far away as Karachi and Kathmandu, died on June 20 at a hospital near his home in Oyster Bay, N.Y. He was 91.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Yana Dlugy
title: Putin Regains His Swagger
description: The Russian president seems to be back to his former self.
content: Hello. This is your Russia-Ukraine War Briefing, a weeknight guide to the latest news and analysis about the conflict.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gregory Schmidt
title: House-Flipping Rate Rises, but Investors’ Profits Are Falling
description: Nearly 10 percent of U.S. homes sold in the first quarter of 2022 were flipped, but investors were challenged by shrinking supply and rising costs.
content: Roughly one in 10 U.S. homes sold during the first quarter of 2022 was flipped, as investors responded to strong demand from buyers. But the profits on those deals fell to a 13-year low, a new report shows.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Eddy
title: Germany’s largest importer of Russian gas is in bailout talks with the government.
description: Uniper, an important energy provider, said it was forced to spend more to buy gas after Gazprom cut deliveries, to just 40 percent of ordered amounts.
content: Uniper, a German energy provider, is talking to the government about a possible bailout, the economy ministry said Thursday, making it the first major utility to seek help since the Russian natural gas giant Gazprom slashed deliveries to Germany two weeks ago.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shira Ovide
title: Post-Roe, Her Facebook Group Went Viral
description: Veronica Risinger made a little online spot for neighbors to share information on abortion. Then 30,000 people joined.
content: When the Supreme Court overturned Roe v. Wade on Friday, Veronica Risinger started what she thought would be a tiny Facebook group for her neighbors in Kansas City., Mo., to share resources for people seeking abortions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Gutierrez and Sui-Lee Wee
title: ‘We Can Trust No One’: Marcos Becomes President in the Philippines
description: The son of the former dictator used his inauguration speech to discuss the economy and the need to heal a deeply divided country after a polarizing election.
content: MANILA — Ferdinand Marcos Jr., the son and namesake of the former dictator, was sworn in Thursday as the 17th president of the Philippines, praising his father’s legacy and pledging to confront an array of challenges as Rodrigo Duterte, the outgoing president, concluded a six-year term.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luke Broadwater, Maggie Haberman, Annie Karni and Alan Feuer
title: Trump Group Pays for Jan. 6 Lawyers, Raising Concerns of Witness Pressure
description: The former president’s political organization and allies have paid for or promised to cover legal fees for witnesses, as the House inquiry suggests he is trying to influence testimony.
content: WASHINGTON — Former President Donald J. Trump's political organization and his allies have paid for or promised to finance the legal fees of more than a dozen witnesses called in the congressional investigation into the Jan. 6 attack, raising legal and ethical questions about whether the former president may be influencing testimony with a direct bearing on him.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ashley Southall and Troy Closson
title: N.Y.P.D.’s Handling of Sex Crimes to Be Investigated by Justice Dept.
description: A civil rights investigation will examine the Police Department’s special victims division, which has long faced troubling accusations from people who reported assaults.
content: The Department of Justice has opened a sweeping investigation of the New York City Police Department’s Special Victims Division and its handling of sex crimes, officials said on Thursday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Laura E. Adkins
title: I’m a New York City Liberal, and I Want a Gun
description: The recent Supreme Court decision on carrying handguns helps people like me.
content: I lived in New York for a decade without fearing for my personal safety. But in recent months, I have been terrified. In May, I filed for and received a temporary order of protection against a former partner.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabella Grullón Paz, Amanda Holpuch and Claire Fahy
title: Suspect in Murder of Off-Road Cyclist Is Arrested in Costa Rica
description: Kaitlin Marie Armstrong had been sought in the killing of Anna Moriah Wilson, who was visiting Texas for a cycling competition when she was fatally shot last month.
content: A woman who had been named as a suspect in the murder of a rising off-road cycling star in Texas last month has been arrested in Costa Rica, the authorities said on Thursday, ending a 43-day search.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Coral Davenport
title: Court Decision Leaves Biden With Few Tools to Combat Climate Change
description: A Supreme Court ruling, combined with an energy crunch and intraparty politics, makes it nearly impossible for President Biden to achieve his climate goals.
content: WASHINGTON — One by one, the tools available to President Biden to fight climate change are being stripped away.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Philip Galanes
title: My Partner Wants to Move His Parents Into Our House. Help!
description: Leery of a renovation plan to accommodate a partner’s aging parents, a reader considers pitching in to buy them a house of their own.
content: My partner’s parents are in their 80s. They are healthy and live independently in another state. My partner wants to move them closer to us in case they need help in the future. The problem: We live in an expensive area, and he can’t afford to buy them a house nearby. So, he wants to convert our home into a duplex. But I don’t want his parents living on top of us! They have no concept of privacy and, worse, a difficult middle-aged daughter who is financially dependent on them and visits for long stretches. Should I offer to contribute financially to a house for his parents that’s a bit farther away from us?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victor Mather
title: Tour de France Preview: Pogacar Leads the Way Once Again
description: As this year’s race gets set to roll in Copenhagen, a guide for how to watch, where the race will go and why Tadej Pogacar is still the class of the peloton.
content: The Tour de France is preparing to roll out of the starting gate again on Friday, with this year’s race set to feature a dominant young champion, a climb up the famous Alpe d’Huez and the debut of a multistage women’s race after the men’s event concludes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adeel Hassan and Christine Chung
title: As vaccines for younger U.S. children roll out, the effects on day care centers may be muted.
description: Federal action to make children older than 6 months eligible for vaccines not only affects parents but also day care centers, which have struggled throughout the pandemic.
content: It is finally their turn. American children ages 6 months through 4 years recently became eligible to receive coronavirus vaccinations, after federal regulators and health officials cleared vaccines from Moderna and Pfizer-BioNTech for very young children.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jay Caspian Kang
title: Liars, Losers and the Lessons of ‘Antiques Roadshow’
description: There is something truly American about hopefully dragging your old stuff to a TV production set.
content: When a writer of my age (42) and sensibilities (vaguely anarchic) is tasked with reporting on PBS’s long-running hit “Antiques Roadshow,” his first impulse is to lengthen the sentences, ramp up the pathos and do his best impression of Hunter S. Thompson’s “The Kentucky Derby Is Decadent and Depraved.” Unfortunately for me, but perhaps to your benefit as the reader, I was accompanied to the “Roadshow” by my parents, who are both in their 70s and not particularly interested in seeing their middle-aged son trying to resurrect the ambitions of his literary youth.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amelia Nierenberg
title: Your Friday Briefing: A Major U.S. Climate Ruling
description: Plus Xi Jinping visits Hong Kong and Ukraine takes back Snake Island.
content: The U.S. Supreme Court limited the Environmental Protection Agency’s powers to restrict carbon emissions from power plants.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patricia Mazzei
title: Florida Judge Will Temporarily Block 15-Week Abortion Ban
description: The ban, passed by Republican lawmakers and signed by Gov. Ron DeSantis, is scheduled to take effect on Friday.
content: MIAMI — In a welcome but likely brief victory for supporters of abortion rights, a judge in Florida blocked a state law banning abortions after 15 weeks of pregnancy on Thursday, the latest in a flurry of activity in state courts and legislatures following the Supreme Court’s decision to overturn Roe v. Wade.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabeth Egan
title: Leila Mottley Graduated From High School and Wrote a Novel
description: The 20-year-old author of “Nightcrawling” has the following work experience: babysitter, preschool teacher, best-selling author.
content: Unless you experienced it firsthand or witnessed it in your own household, it would be hard to articulate the discombobulating boomerang effect of the pandemic on young adults who had just left home. For Leila Mottley, an Oakland, Calif., native who was midway through her second semester at Smith College, there was an added logistical and creative wrinkle: When she received word that she had three days to pack up her room and vacate the campus, her debut novel was about to be sent to publishers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra Stevenson, Zixu Wang and Austin Ramzy
title: Xi visits Hong Kong amid high security and inside a Covid bubble.
description: HONG KONG — Since the pandemic erupted in 2020, China’s top leader, Xi Jinping, has been hunkered down in a virus-free bubble within his country’s closed borders. On Thursday, he left the safe confines of the mainland for the first time, arriving in Hong Kong for a tightly scripted visit aimed at reinforcing his authority over the city.
content: HONG KONG — Since the pandemic erupted in 2020, China’s top leader, Xi Jinping, has been hunkered down in a virus-free bubble within his country’s closed borders. On Thursday, he left the safe confines of the mainland for the first time, arriving in Hong Kong for a tightly scripted visit aimed at reinforcing his authority over the city.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Facing a Surge in Violence, Retail Workers Want to Fight Back
description: Quotation of the Day for Thursday, June 30, 2022.
content: “If an employee gets caught stealing a candy bar, they get fired. But you have shoplifters who come in here and steal a whole buggy full of Tide.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Trish Bendix
title: Seth Meyers Calls Out Fox News Hosts for Falling Speechless
description: Meyers said hosts couldn’t “settle on a coherent narrative the way they usually do,” as indicated by a long, awkward pause during a live broadcast about Cassidy Hutchinson’s testimony.
content: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Clay Risen
title: Sonny Barger, Face of the Hells Angels, Dies at 83
description: He cultivated the motorcycle club’s outlaw image and was a pivotal figure in its emergence as an emblem of West Coast rebellion in the 1960s.
content: Sonny Barger, who as the charismatic face of the Hells Angels grew the hard-charging motorcycle club from its roots in the San Francisco area into a global phenomenon, in the process making it an emblem of West Coast rebellion — and, federal authorities said, criminal enterprise — died on Wednesday at his home outside Oakland, Calif. He was 83.
source.name: The New York Times

title: How does The New York Times handle corrections?
description: Explaining the policies and processes that define our journalism.
content: We recognize an ethical responsibility to correct all factual errors, large and small, promptly and in a prominent space. We encourage readers to reach out to us at nytnews@nytimes.com when they spot a possible mistake.
source.name: The New York Times

title: How does The New York Times report on mass shootings?
description: Explaining the policies and processes that define our journalism.
content: The National desk receives reports of active gunman situations in the United States at least once a day. We begin by monitoring the situation and confirming details. Within 24 hours of the mass shooting at Marjory Stoneman Douglas High School in Parkland, Fla., in 2018, The Times had at least 25 reporters and 15 editors working on the story.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Futterman
title: At Wimbledon, American Men Are Putting on a Fourth of July Bash
description: Nearly everywhere one looked on Wednesday and Thursday, an American man was slamming or slicing or grinding his way into the final 32, and it feels like the 1990s.
content: WIMBLEDON, England — Just in time for the Fourth of July weekend, the American men are throwing a party on British soil.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Contemporary Authors on Their Favorite New York City Novels
description: These writers, who have themselves set fiction in the city, weigh in on novels by others who have done the same.
content: Last week, T published a list of the 25 most significant New York City novels from the last 100 years, which we compiled based on a discussion (with some friendly debate) by five panelists: the writers Michael Cunningham, Mark Harris, Katie Kitamura and Branden Jacobs-Jenkins, and the bookseller Miriam Chotiner-Gardner. Given that reading preferences are so subjective, however, and that New York City looms large in the actual and literary lives of many, we wanted to bring others into the conversation, too. Here are some of the titles that authors who have themselves written fiction set in New York — Eileen Myles, Candace Bushnell and T’s editor in chief, Hanya Yanagihara, among them — would nominate for a list of their own.
source.name: The New York Times

title: The Weather Men
description: It’s all cool.
content: Who knows how many so-called fashion influencers would dress if no one paid them or there wasn’t a camera around? Others, however, are genuinely stylish with a lot to teach us about dressing with verve while also relishing the process. Case in point, three gentlemen captured at the men’s wear shows in Paris and Milan.  Guy Trebay
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Noah Weiland
title: F.D.A. Says Next Covid Boosters Should Target Omicron Subvariants
description: The decision was an acknowledgment that the current shots may no longer be as protective for at least some Americans by the time a possible fall or winter surge arrives.
content: WASHINGTON — The Food and Drug Administration said on Thursday that it had advised coronavirus vaccine manufacturers to update their booster formulations to target the fast-spreading Omicron subvariants known as BA.4 and BA.5, which are now estimated to account for more than half of new virus cases in the United States.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael D. Shear and Jim Tankersley
title: Biden, Chiding Court, Endorses Ending Filibuster to Codify Abortion Rights
description: The president called the Supreme Court’s decision overturning Roe v. Wade “destabilizing’’ and said Congress needed to act to codify it into law.
content: MADRID — President Biden on Thursday condemned what he called the “outrageous behavior” of the Supreme Court in overturning Roe v. Wade and said for the first time that he supported ending the filibuster to protect a woman’s right to an abortion and a broader constitutional right to privacy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amelia Nierenberg
title: Your Thursday Briefing
description: A prisoner exchange in Ukraine.
content: Ukraine announced the largest prisoner exchange since Russia invaded, saying 144 soldiers were being returned to Ukraine, including dozens who had fought in the siege of Mariupol. The same number of Russian and pro-Russian personnel were returned.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma Goldberg
title: Media companies expand health coverage after the Supreme Court abortion ruling.
description: News organizations join other businesses that will reimburse employees who need to travel to access reproductive health care.
content: Since the Supreme Court’s ruling on abortion, some media companies have wrestled with a complex issue: how to balance their news coverage with the desire to expand their policies to protect reproductive health care for their employees.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Niki Kitsantonis
title: In Athens Creativity in Art, Food and More Rises
description: The Greek capital has added impressive arts venues, daring restaurants and a blossoming hotel scene to its well-known Classical draws.
content: Here’s a surprise: While Athenians were locked down because of the pandemic, a flurry of creative and entrepreneurial activity was underway. The outcome? A total of 272 new restaurants, according to the local industry association, as well as hundreds more cafes and bars. The city also acquired 34 new hotels, offering 1,982 rooms over the last two years. And its cultural landscape blossomed, with major national projects coming to fruition.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Remy Tumin
title: Your Thursday Evening Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
content: (Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabella Simonetti
title: After Stock Market’s Worst Start in 50 Years, Some See More Pain Ahead
description: At the halfway point of the year, it’s been a historically horrible time for stocks. Bonds are in bad shape, too.
content: Wall Street set records in the first half of the year, none of them good.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joseph Giovannini
title: 2 Art Havens in the Hudson Valley Offer Nature Indoors and Out
description: Magazzino Italian Art Museum in Cold Spring, N.Y., and the Russel Wright Design Center in nearby Garrison deliver ecological messages (meadows, donkeys, and a waterfall included).
content: Back in 1967, Arte Povera artists in Italy, the radicals of their time, hung out at the Piper Club, a discothèque of, by and for the avant-garde in Turin. During one nocturnal happening, young women danced in tunics made of polyurethane birch logs and ponchos studded with foam rocks to look like riverbeds. Like nature sprites, the dancers gamboled over “nature carpets,” rugs crafted of foam by the Turinese artist Piero Gilardi. Guests sipped their Camparis reclining on simulated cabbage patches.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stanley Reed
title: OPEC Plus lifts its oil output target to prepandemic levels.
description: The group confirmed its decision to restore production to about 44 million barrels a day. But difficult questions remain about its relationships with Russia and the United States.
content: Officials from OPEC, Russia and other oil-producing countries decided on Thursday to confirm the decision taken last month to lift output by 648,000 barrels per day in August.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Liptak
title: Supreme Court Limits E.P.A.’s Ability to Restrict Power Plant Emissions
description: The case considered the Environmental Protection Agency’s powers under the Clean Air Act.
content: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court on Thursday limited the Environmental Protection Agency’s ability to regulate carbon emissions from power plants, making it much tougher for President Biden to achieve his goal of cutting greenhouse gas emissions in half by the end of the decade.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ron Lieber and Audra Melton
title: Where an Army Paycheck Is an Easy Target
description: An entire financial ecosystem surrounds the nation’s military installations. It’s a perilous landscape for young soldiers with little financial experience.
content: OAK GROVE, Ky. — Go out Gate 5 at Fort Campbell and Jenna’s Adult Superstore is right across the street. On either side are easy ways to lose your shirt.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Manuela Andreoni
title: The climate math just got harder
description: The Supreme Court has said the E.P.A. can’t broadly regulate greenhouse gas emissions from power plants. We look at what it means.
content: The Supreme Court has issued one of the most important environmental rulings ever, which will make the battle against global warming even more difficult.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Deb Amlen
title: Top Gear
description: Samuel A. Donaldson and Doug Peterson, both veteran constructors, return to break things up a bit.
content: THURSDAY PUZZLE — There are puzzles you solve just because it has become a habit, and there are puzzles you solve that stop you in your tracks because you’ve encountered something really special. These special puzzles are recognizable for the effect they have on the solver. You solve, you don’t quite understand what’s going on and then the whole conceit hits you all at once.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eric Asimov
title: On the Sonoma Coast, Fog, Wind and Exceptional Wine
description: At Peay Vineyards, a coastal pioneer, reflecting on the evolution of an appellation, following one’s muse and seeing tastes grow more diverse.
content: ANNAPOLIS, Calif. — At Peay Vineyards, 53 acres of vines on a ridge near this tiny town just 3.5 miles from the Pacific Ocean, the fog generally burns off by around 9 a.m. and the air begins to warm up, at least for a little while. By midday, a breeze starts to blow, ruffling the leaves of the towering redwoods and getting stronger until the fog rolls in again in the late afternoon.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alanis Thames
title: Equity in Sports Has Focused on Gender, Not Race. So Gaps Persist.
description: Title IX, over 50 years, has heavily benefited white women over women of color. That’s partly because race has never been part of the law.
content: In 1998, Traci Green and her Florida teammates posed with an N.C.A.A. women’s tennis championship trophy after defeating Duke in five of six matchups. Green, who received a full scholarship to Florida, smiled proudly, graciously.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victor Mather
title: ‘If Each Day Was Going to Be My Last, I’m Going to Enjoy It’
description: After nine long years, Mark Appel, the No. 1 overall pick in the 2013 draft, finally made his major league debut.
content: It’s always worth noting when a No. 1 overall draft pick makes his major league debut. But when Mark Appel took the mound for the Philadelphia Phillies on Wednesday night, it wasn’t the usual story of a phenom starting a career with the expectation of years of greatness ahead.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Alice Elliott Dark Ruins Books by Reading in the Bathtub
description: “I easily fall asleep and end up with a soggy bloated creature rather than a legible book,” says the author, whose new novel is “Fellowship Point.” “This works out well for the authors, as I always go buy another copy.”
content: I keep “Upstream,” by Mary Oliver, and “Me & Other Writing,” by Marguerite Duras, by my bed and dip into them regularly. Both those books return me to my deeper purpose as a human and as a writer. I am reading “Crossroads,” by Jonathan Franzen, “Trust,” by Hernan Diaz, “Swann’s Way,” by Marcel Proust, “Ancestor Trouble,” by Maud Newton, and forthcoming books by Eliza Minot, Laila Halaby and Laura Spence-Ash. I listen to “The Lonely City,” by Olivia Laing, read by Susan Lyons, to go to sleep. I know it by heart!
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Vivian Giang, Stephen Gandel, Lauren Hirsch, Ephrat Livni and Jenny Gross
title: Reconsidering Privacy Risks After Roe
description: Many women are worried that their data might be used against them — whether it’s period tracking apps, digital receipts or other information collected by companies.
content: In the post-Roe era, when abortion may be illegal in much of the country, many women are worried that their data might be used against them — whether it’s digital receipts, period tracking apps or the vast trove of personal information collected and disseminated every day by tech companies large and small.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sadiba Hasan
title: In ‘Stranger Things,’ He Delivers Pizza and Stoned Comic Relief
description: Eduardo Franco, who joined the Netflix hit this season, has carved out a role as the show’s addled but reliably hilarious tension-release valve.
content: The “Stranger Things” gang in Lenora Hills, Calif., is in danger — shots are being fired, and an agent is bleeding out. The camera switches abruptly to a view of an unknowing Argyle, played by Eduardo Franco, pulling up to the Byerses’ home as the catchy reggae hit “Pass the Dutchie” blares from his pizza delivery van.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicole Sperling and John Koblin
title: Netflix Says It’s Business as Usual. Is That Good Enough?
description: Long Hollywood’s leading innovator, the streaming service is staying the course, despite serious challenges to its business and questions about its content.
content: While being honored at the Banff Film Festival in Canada in early June, Bela Bajaria, Netflix’s head of global television, surprised some with what she didn’t say. Despite the recent turmoil at the streaming giant — including a loss of subscribers, hundreds of job cuts and a precipitous stock drop — she said Netflix was charging ahead, with no significant plans to change its programming efforts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Abrams and Tania Ganguli
title: Brittney Griner’s Trial in Russia Is Starting, and Likely to End in a Conviction
description: Courts in Russia heavily favor the prosecution, experts said, pointing to a prisoner swap as perhaps the W.N.B.A. star’s best chance to come home.
content: More than four months after she was first detained, the W.N.B.A. star Brittney Griner is expected to appear in a Russian courtroom on Friday for the start of a trial on drug charges that legal experts said was all but certain to end in a conviction despite the clamor in the United States for her release.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isaac Aronow and Doug Mennella
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: THURSDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Blake Hounshell and Kate Zernike
title: A 30,000-Foot View of the Abortion Ruling’s Political Fallout
description: What will happen in the midterms? How are state-by-state battles unfolding? What about the Supreme Court’s legitimacy? We spoke with Kate Zernike, a Times reporter who has been covering the abortion debate.
content: The Supreme Court’s ruling last week overturning Roe v. Wade has roiled the country and shifted the main struggle over abortion rights from the courtroom to the political arena.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alisha Haridasani Gupta and Dani Blum
title: Does Plan B Have a Weight Limit?
description: Researchers have looked into why and how weight influences emergency contraception but have come up against several unknowns. Here’s what we know.
content: In 2011, a team of researchers in Scotland were investigating why the emergency contraceptive pill, commonly known as Plan B, seemed to fail in a small portion of the population, and made an alarming discovery: the pill failed at higher rates among women with a higher B.M.I., or body mass index.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jim Tankersley and Michael D. Shear
title: Missing From Biden’s Europe Trip: An Endgame for War and Cheaper Gas
description: The G7 and NATO meetings this week underscored the pressure on Western leaders caused by soaring energy costs resulting from Russia’s invasion of Ukraine.
content: MADRID — President Biden issued a grim warning to Americans after Russian troops invaded Ukraine in February: standing up to President Vladimir V. Putin could hurt the U.S. economy. “I will not pretend this will be painless,” he said in remarks delivered in the East Room of the White House.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Devika Girish
title: ‘Clara Sola’ Review: Breaking Free
description: A 40-year-old woman, believed to be blessed with divine powers, has her sexual awakening in Nathalie Álvarez Mesén’s debut feature.
content: A sad paradox of being a woman in this world is that the more one is exalted — as a goddess, a saint, a provider — the less one is allowed to be a person, flawed and whole. Such is the predicament of the heroine of Nathalie Álvarez Mesén’s debut feature, “Clara Sola.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Coral Davenport
title: What Is the Clean Air Act?
description: The legislation is the source of scores of landmark regulations on air pollution.
content: The Clean Air Act, which some legal experts call the most powerful environmental law in the world, was enacted in 1970, at the birth of the environmental movement.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maya Phillips
title: Review: In a Powerful ‘Hamlet,’ a Fragile Prince Faces His Foes
description: Alex Lawther makes for an especially riveting hero in Robert Icke’s chic if imperfect modern-dress production at the Park Avenue Armory.
content: Many Hamlets I’ve seen are wily. Some kooky. Narcissistic, aloof, even pretentious. Less common is a Hamlet who is tender and romantic and achingly vulnerable, like a petal falling from the head of a flower at the end of its bloom.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sharon Otterman
title: As Monkeypox Cases Rise, New York Will Distribute 8,000 Vaccine Doses
description: The city quickly ran out of doses during an earlier distribution effort, at a single clinic in Chelsea, after hundreds of people lined up for the vaccine.
content: New York has emerged as a hot spot for a growing monkeypox outbreak, but as the city prepares to receive thousands of doses of vaccine, it is unclear how the city will distribute them equitably to the people most at risk for the disease: sexually active gay, bisexual and other men who have sex with men, among whom the global outbreak has been centered.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephen Gandel
title: A former hedge fund star wins a record $52 million in a defamation case.
description: An arbitration settlement ends a dispute between D.E. Shaw and one of its former partners, Daniel Michalow, who was ousted over sexual misconduct allegations.
content: A former Wall Street star who was ousted from a top hedge fund amid allegations of sexual harassment at the start of the #MeToo movement has won a record defamation award against his former firm, D.E. Shaw, and four of the firm’s senior executives, according to a filing by a panel of arbitrators on Thursday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By ‘First Person'
title: She’s Gay and a Republican. Is There a Place for Her in the G.O.P.?
description: With the recent Republican rollbacks on L.G.B.T.Q. rights, Jerri Ann Henry wonders whether she has a future in the party.
content: Being gay and Republican never felt like identities that were at odds to Jerri Ann Henry. She grew up in a conservative Christian family in Texas and was door-knocking for local politicians from the time she could walk. Later, she became a loud voice in the fight for marriage equality as the head of the group Young Conservatives for the Freedom to Marry and led the Log Cabin Republicans, a group representing gay conservatives.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Glenn Thrush, Luke Broadwater and Michael S. Schmidt
title: Hutchinson Testimony Exposes Tensions Between Parallel Jan. 6 Inquiries
description: That the House panel did not provide the Justice Department with transcripts of Cassidy Hutchinson’s interviews speaks to the panel’s reluctance to turn over evidence.
content: WASHINGTON — The explosive testimony of a former Trump White House aide on Tuesday may have increased the likelihood of new prosecutions stemming from the attack on the Capitol, but it also bared lingering conflicts between the Justice Department and congressional investigators.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Casselman and Jeanna Smialek
title: Income and Spending Lag Behind Inflation, a Sign of Economic Fragility
description: After the latest monthly consumer data, some analysts expect a second straight quarter of decline in the U.S. gross domestic product.
content: Americans’ income and spending failed to keep pace with rising prices in May, the latest sign that the fastest inflation in a generation is chipping away at the bedrock of the economic recovery.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra Stevenson, Zixu Wang and Austin Ramzy
title: China’s Leader Hails a Hong Kong ‘Reborn From Ashes’ Amid Crackdown
description: Before Xi Jinping’s tightly controlled appearance, Hong Kong sent officials, diplomats and others to hotels for days of isolation and Covid tests.
content: HONG KONG — Since the pandemic erupted in 2020, China’s top leader, Xi Jinping, has been hunkered down in a virus-free bubble within his country’s closed borders. On Thursday, he left the safe confines of the mainland for the first time, arriving in Hong Kong for a tightly scripted visit aimed at reinforcing his authority over the city.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Morales
title: Family Recipes Etched in Stone. Gravestone, That Is.
description: They say you can’t take it with you, but recipes do disappear when loved ones die. These families have found a novel way to record them for posterity.
content: At his home in Washington, D.C., Charlie McBride often bakes his mother’s recipe for peach cobbler. As he pours the topping over the fruit, he remembers how his mother, aunts and grandmother sat under a tree in Louisiana, cackling at one another’s stories as they peeled peaches to can for the winter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joumana Khatib
title: 12 New Books Coming in July
description: Dive into a tender coming-of-age memoir by Isaac Fitzgerald, a biography of Vladimir V. Putin and novels from Silvia Moreno-Garcia, Bolu Babalola and Daniel Nieh.
content: In 2016, Pringle, an investigative journalist for The Los Angeles Times, received what turned out to be a career-changing tip: The dean of University of Southern California’s medical school was linked to a drug overdose. As he continued reporting, Pringle, a Pulitzer-winning journalist, realized that the scandal was only the beginning and would result in a bombshell investigation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ed Shanahan
title: Woman Is Fatally Shot While Pushing Baby in Stroller on Upper East Side
description: The shooting occurred near the intersection of Lexington Avenue and 95th Street, the police said. The victim’s 3-month-old child was unhurt.
content: A 20-year-old woman was fatally shot Wednesday night by a hooded gunman while she pushed her 3-month-old child in a stroller on the Upper East Side, officials said, another bleak episode in a wave of gun violence that has gripped New York City over the past two years.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kurtis Lee
title: As Dockworkers Near Contract’s End, Many Others Have a Stake
description: West Coast longshoremen and port operators say they’re determined to reach an agreement, but truckers and retailers relying on cargo are uneasy.
content: LOS ANGELES — David Alvarado barreled south along the highway, staring through the windshield of his semi truck toward the towering cranes along the coastline.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By A.J. Goldmann
title: In Munich, Young Directors Offer Horrors Both Real and Fantastical
description: The Radikal Jung festival transports theatergoers to Russia’s 2014 invasion of eastern Ukraine and an American high school in the Middle Ages.
content: MUNICH — At the end of a recent performance of “Bad Roads” here, the play’s Ukrainian director, Tamara Trunova, thanked the audience for staying for the entire 180-minute production, a harrowing succession of vignettes set in the Donbas region of eastern Ukraine, which Russia invaded in 2014, eight years before it undertook a larger war against Ukraine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Claudia Gryvatz Copquin and Jill P. Capuzzo
title: Homes for Sale on Long Island and in New Jersey
description: This week’s available properties include a five-bedroom home in East Hills, N.Y., and a five-bedroom house on seven acres in Robbinsville, N.J.
content: Click on the slide show to see this week’s featured properties:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chelsia Rose Marcius, Ali Watkins and Ashley Southall
title: Police Eye Domestic Violence in Upper East Side Killing of Mother
description: Azsia Johnson, 20, hoped to be a pediatric nurse and was a doting mother to her two children, her mother said. She was shot at point blank range while walking her 3-month-old daughter.
content: Azsia Johnson loved children, especially babies. Growing up in Crown Heights, she hoped to become a pediatric nurse, and doted on her own two children — a toddler and a three-month-old baby girl.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eleanore Park
title: 12 Can’t-Miss Summer Pastas
description: At a potluck or on the weeknight table, these fresh, hearty dishes are sure to leave people asking for the recipes.
content: It’s the season of grilled showstoppers and big, easy desserts, but summer pastas may just be the unsung heroes of seasonal cookouts and busy weeknights. Potentially portable, frequently vegetarian and reliably comforting, these recipes from New York Times Cooking can shine at a potluck or be thrown together as an easy dinner for two, with leftovers you’ll definitely look forward to.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kenji Yoshino
title: Is the Right to Same-Sex Marriage Next?
description: Why the Supreme Court should not overturn the right to same-sex marriage.
content: While the Supreme Court’s opinion in Dobbs v. Jackson Women’s Health Organization is already catastrophic in its effects on reproductive rights and the equal treatment of women in this country, it has also led to speculation that the court’s conservative supermajority is just getting started in rolling back fundamental rights. To be sure, Justice Samuel Alito’s majority opinion is at pains to say that “nothing in this opinion should be understood to cast doubt on precedents that do not concern abortion.” Yet that statement rings false.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luis Ferré-Sadurní and Grace Ashford
title: N.Y. Democrats to Pass New Gun Laws in Response to Supreme Court Ruling
description: Lawmakers convened a special session in Albany on Thursday to pass measures that would prohibit concealed weapons in many public places.
content: ALBANY, N.Y. — One week after the Supreme Court struck down a law limiting the spread of concealed handguns in New York, state Democratic leaders on Thursday were expected to respond with new measures that would prohibit people from carrying firearms in many public settings deemed “sensitive places.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kellen Browning
title: Uber Says Sexual Assaults Are Down but Rate of Traffic Deaths Is Up
description: The company’s second safety report, delayed by the pandemic, is part of a campaign to assure customers that its rides are not dangerous.
content: Uber said in a safety report on Thursday that sexual assaults in its ride-hailing vehicles were down significantly since its last report but that the rate of fatal car crashes had increased.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rachel Felder
title: Overlooked No More: Klaus Nomi, Singer With an Otherworldly Persona
description: His sound and look influenced everyone from Anohni to Lady Gaga. He also sang backup vocals for David Bowie.
content: This article is part of Overlooked, a series of obituaries about remarkable people whose deaths, beginning in 1851, went unreported in The Times.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tyler Kepner
title: For the Mets, the Cavalry Rides in on a Rumble Pony
description: Max Scherzer got in some rehab work with a minor league team and is set to rejoin the Mets — a team that forgot how to hit while he was away.
content: HARTFORD, Conn. — An ace right-hander with 3,000 strikeouts and a Hall of Fame résumé took the mound at Citi Field on Wednesday afternoon. He fired eight shutout innings against a first-place team on his way to a victory. It lined up precisely with the Mets’ vision for their summer, except for one big detail.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charles M. Blow
title: Women Will Save Us
description: In the face of recent threats to the country, women have stepped up more than men.
content: Men are pack animals.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kara Swisher
title: Resisting the Worst of the Web Is Not Futile
description: Tech moguls may be more powerful — and unholy — than ever, but consumers don’t have to be complacent.
content: For my first column in The New York Times, nearly four years ago, I wrote about a topic I thought everyone desperately needed to hear at the time, using one of the world’s most important media platforms, pretty much because I knew it would make a lot more people pay attention.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brian Seibert
title: America, Prismatic and Distressed, Seen Through Dance
description: At Jacob’s Pillow, the Ted Shawn Theater has reopened with the inclusive “America(na) to Me” and a premiere by Ronald K. Brown/Evidence.
content: BECKET, Mass. — Among the main attractions of the Jacob’s Pillow Dance Festival is its bucolic setting here in the Berkshires. But the news this year is a return to the great indoors. In 2020, the twin blows of the pandemic and a fire that burned down one of the festival’s two theaters forced a cancellation of all performances. Last year, the shows were outside, weather permitting.
